title: Progressive Asymmetric Sensorineural Hearing Loss with Disproportionate Speech Perception Deficit
chief_complaint: I have noticed a decrease in my hearing and an increase in ringing in my right ear over the last 6 months. I stopped using my right hearing aid because it doesn't seem to help anymore.

problem_summary.onset: Hearing difficulty began approximately 14 years ago; acute worsening in the right ear 6 months ago.
problem_summary.course: Progressive; started 14 years ago, amplification started 9 years ago, recent decline.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral, but currently worse in the right ear.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient discontinued use of right hearing aid due to perceived lack of benefit.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation due to recent changes and inability to adjust hearing aid for benefit.

history.present_illness: 38-year-old female with a 14-year history of hearing loss. In the last 6 months, she noticed decreased hearing and increased tinnitus in the right ear.
history.prior_management: Amplification use for 9 years; current aids are 2 years old. Stopped using right aid recently.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal at 250 Hz, sloping to profound sensorineural hearing loss at 6-8 kHz. Left ear: Normal at 250 Hz, sloping to severe sensorineural hearing loss at 8 kHz. Asymmetric configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT agrees with PTA bilaterally. Significant asymmetry in Word Recognition Scores (WRS). Right ear WRS is very poor (42%) and disproportionate to the pure-tone loss compared to the Left ear (82%).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right Ipsi: Normal at 500 Hz, elevated/absent higher. Left Ipsi: Normal 500-2000 Hz. Contralateral reflexes show abnormalities. Reflex decay negative where measurable.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral, asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, sloping from normal in the low frequencies to severe/profound in the high frequencies. The right ear shows significantly poorer thresholds and, critically, a disproportionately poor word recognition score (42%) compared to the left ear (82%). Tympanometry is normal.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms a decrease in hearing in your right ear compared to the left.
More importantly, the clarity of speech in your right ear is significantly reduced (42%), which explains why the hearing aid volume isn't helpingâ€”making sounds louder isn't making them clearer.
Because of the difference between your ears and the sudden change, I am referring you to an ENT physician.
The physician will likely order an MRI to rule out any issues along the hearing nerve (retrocochlear pathology) that could explain these symptoms.
We will hold off on adjusting or replacing your hearing aids until we have medical clearance from the ENT.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is frustrated that their hearing aid 'stopped working' and is anxious about the new ringing in the right ear.
When the audiologist explains the poor speech score in the right ear, express concern about whether it can be fixed.
You have a family history of hearing loss, so you assumed this was just genetic progression, but the asymmetry is new to you.
